attributes.title: Effects of Diabetes Prevalence Information
attributes.description: In 2015, 30.3 million Americans have diabetes (9.4% of U.S. adults), and 114.4 million Americans have prediabetes or diabetes (43.3% of U.S. adults). Health news stories and health campaigns frequently feature diabetes prevalence information. This study examines the effects of diabetes prevalence information.

q2.value:
H1: People will overestimate diabetes prevalence in the absence of any prevalence information. 
H2: Exposure to diabetes prevalence statistics in percentage formats will reduce the degree of overestimation of diabetes prevalence. 
H3: Exposure to prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics in percentage formats will increase the degree of overestimation of diabetes prevalence. 
RQ1: How does exposure to high diabetes prevalence assertions without statistics affect diabetes prevalence estimates?
RQ2: How does exposure to diabetes prevalence statistics in raw frequency formats affect diabetes prevalence estimates? 
RQ3: How does exposure to prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics in raw frequency formats affect diabetes prevalence estimates?
H4: Mediation: prevalence information will influence diabetes prevalence estimates, which in turn will affect perceived susceptibility of diabetes.
H5: Mediation: prevalence information will influence diabetes prevalence estimates, which in turn will affect perceived severity of diabetes for the society.
H6: Mediation: prevalence information will influence diabetes prevalence estimates, which in turn will affect the degree to which readers attribute diabetes to social causes.
H7: Mediation: prevalence information will affect diabetes prevalence estimates, which in turn will influence behavioral intentions to prevent/control diabetes. 
H8: Mediation: prevalence information will affect diabetes prevalence estimates, which in turn will influence diabetes related policy support.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study uses a between subjects design manipulating 1 factor (diabetes prevalence message) that has 7 levels (no message control; message without prevalence information; message stating high prevalence of diabetes without providing statistics; diabetes prevalence statistics [raw frequency]; diabetes prevalence statistics [percentage]; prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics [raw frequency]; prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics [percentage]).

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the seven message manipulation conditions using the Qualtrics survey system.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Respondents will be recruited by Prolific Academic. After completing the study, participants will receive compensation according to Prolific Academic's policies. U.S. adults are eligible to take the survey.

Diabetes prevalence message (a categorical variable with 7 levels): no message control; message without prevalence information; message stating high prevalence of diabetes without providing statistics; diabetes prevalence statistics [raw frequency]; diabetes prevalence statistics [percentage]; prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics [raw frequency]; prediabetes-diabetes combined prevalence statistics [percentage].
Diabetes prevalence estimates; Perceived susceptibility, severity, and social causes of diabetes; Behavioral intentions to prevent/control diabetes; Diabetes related policy support

Pairwise comparisons comparing experimental conditions to the control condition (baseline).
Mediation analysis focusing on indirect effects: prevalence information will affect prevalence estimates, which in turn will influence other perceptions, behavioral intentions and policy support.

q20.value: Respondents who read the message stimulus in less than 5 seconds.

attributes.title: Behavioural characteristics associated with successful weight loss in overweight and obese women undergoing a 14-week diet
attributes.description:
The purpose of this study is to understand whether free-living movement behaviours (physical activity [PA], sedentary behaviour [SB] and sleep) and free-living eating behaviours (total energy intake [EI] and/or macronutrient composition) predict clinically significant weight loss (≥5%) following a weight loss diet. The study is a secondary analysis of data collected from a trial that is reported in detail elsewhere (Buckland et al. 2018) and registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (#NCT02012426). Women participants with overweight or obesity followed a 14-week weight loss diet. Outcome measure including body mass, body composition, waist circumference, resting metabolic rate, free-living movement behaviours and free-living eating behaviours were completed at the start and the end of the weight loss programmes.

Buckland, N.J., et al., A Low Energy–Dense Diet in the Context of a Weight-Management Program Affects Appetite Control in Overweight and Obese Women. The Journal of Nutrition, 2018. 148(5): p. 798-806.

q1.value: Anna Myers, Diana Camidge, Fiona Croden, Catherine Gibbons, Stephen Whybrow, Graham Finlayson, John Blundell, Nicola Buckland

q2.value: Early and post-intervention changes in free-living PA, SB, sleep and energy and macronutrient intake will explain variability in diet-induced weight loss. Individuals who exhibit a poor weight loss outcome will show greater EI and SB and less PA and sleep compared to those who exhibit weight loss success.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

BM was measured with shoes and heavy clothing removed on the first day of the weight management programme using electronic scales. Participants’ self-reported adherence to the intervention each week by responding to ‘How well have you managed to stick with the weight control programme?’ on a 100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS) anchored at each end with ‘Not at all well’ and ‘Very well’. Between weeks 2 and 14 participants visited the laboratory in the Human Appetite Research Unit (HARU) at the University of Leeds for measurement days. Participants received payment of £250 on completion of the study to reimburse them for their time and expenses. The study procedures and all study materials were reviewed and approved by the School of Psychology Ethics Board at the University of Leeds (14-0090).

question.value:
Participants
The study is a secondary analysis of data collected from a trial that is reported in more detail elsewhere, see above reference (ClinicalTrials.gov #NCT02012426). Women participants with overweight or obesity (aged 18-65 years; body mass index (BMI) 28-45 kg/m2) were recruited by advertisement from the University of Leeds. Inclusion criteria were: provided written informed consent, healthy women, aged 18-65 years, BMI between 28-45 kg/m2, reporting an interest in weight loss and not actively participating in a commercial weight loss programme, not increased PA levels in the past 4 weeks, able to eat most everyday foods and fruits and vegetables. Exclusion criteria were: significant health problems, taking any medication or supplements known to affect appetite or weight, pregnant, planning to become pregnant or breastfeeding, history of anaphylaxis to food, known food allergies or food intolerance, smokers and those who have recently ceased smoking (within the last 3 months), participants receiving systemic or local treatment likely to interfere with evaluation of the study parameters, those who have taken part in a commercial weight loss programme in the last 2 months, individuals who work in appetite or feeding related areas, unable to consume foods used in the study, individuals who have had bariatric surgery, history of an eating disorder, presence of untreated hypothyroidism, insufficient English language skills to complete study questionnaires. 
Design
The study was a non-randomised, parallel group design to explore whether there are behavioural characteristics associated with ≥5% or ≤3% weight loss following a 14-week diet. BM was measured with shoes and heavy clothing removed on the first day of the weight management programme using electronic scales. Participants’ self-reported adherence to the intervention each week by responding to ‘How well have you managed to stick with the weight control programme?’ on a 100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS) anchored at each end with ‘Not at all well’ and ‘Very well’. Between weeks 2 and 14 participants visited the laboratory in the Human Appetite Research Unit (HARU) at the University of Leeds for measurement days. Participants received payment of £250 on completion of the study to reimburse them for their time and expenses. The study procedures and all study materials were reviewed and approved by the School of Psychology Ethics Board at the University of Leeds (14-0090).
Weight management programme
Participants either followed the commercial diet (Slimming World) or the self-led diet (NHS Choices) for the 14-week intervention period. The commercial diet encouraged ad libitum intake of low energy dense foods as part of a balanced diet, with weekly weigh-ins, group support, weight loss goals and access to online support. The self-led diet group accessed free online resource and a self-led diet programme which recommends reducing calorie intake by 600 kcal/d. Both diet programmes also encouraged individuals to self-monitor and to increase the amount of physical activity they do.
For the purpose of this study, data were analysed with both diet intervention groups combined and participants were then categorised based on their percentage change in BM, but programme type was controlled for in all analyses. There were no specific research questions pertaining to the type of diet used to induce weight loss. Rather, the study sought to explore behavioural characteristics associated with the degree of diet-induced weight loss success.
Procedures
BM was measured on the first day of the weight management programme using electronic scales (commercial diet group: recorded as part of their first weigh-in at a support group meeting; self-led diet group: recorded by a researcher at the HARU). BM was measured with shoes and heavy clothing removed.
For all laboratory visits (measures and probe days) participants were instructed to be fasted from 10:00 pm the previous night and to abstain from strenuous exercise and alcohol consumption for at least 24 hours before all laboratory visits. Compliance was checked on arrival via self-report.
Measures days
Participants completed two measurement days; one during week 2 and one during week 14 at the end of the intervention. Resting metabolic rate (RMR) was measured (GEM, NutrEn Technology Ltd, Cheshire, UK) with participants laying supine for 40 min during which expired air was collected using a ventilated hood system. VO2 and VCO2 values were sampled every 30 seconds. The average of the final 30 min values was deemed to be the RMR expressed as kcal/d. BM and body composition (fat mass (FM) and fat-free mass (FFM)) were measured using the BODPOD (Body Composition Tracking System, Life Measurement, Inc., Concord, USA) which uses air displacement plethysmography. Participants wore tight clothing and a swim cap to allow for an accurate measure of body volume. Height was measured using a stadiometer (Seca Ltd., Birmingham, UK) and waist circumference (WC) was measured horizontally in line with the umbilicus. 
Free-living energy intake
Participants completed a 7-day weighed food diary during weeks 3 and 12. Electronic scales and training were provided to ensure detailed descriptions (e.g. brands) and consumed weights of foods and beverages were reported. Total EI, macronutrient composition and energy density were calculated from the food diary. Energy density was calculated from the contribution of all food and milks (excluded all other drinks) (total EI divided by total weight intake) based on criteria previously used (Wrieden et al. 2015). Data were analysed using WISP 4.0 (Tinuviel Software 2013).
Free-living physical activity, sedentary behaviour and energy expenditure
Free-living PA and SB was objectively measured during week 3 and 12 using the SenseWear Armband mini (SWA; BodyMedia, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA), as has previously been described (Myers et al., 2016). Participants were instructed to wear the SWA on the posterior surface of their upper non-dominant arm for a minimum of 22 hour/d for ≥6 days (except for the time spent showering, bathing or swimming). For the SWA data to be valid >22 hours of data per day had to be recorded on at least five days (midnight to midnight) including at least one weekend day.
Classification of responders and non-responders
To identify differences that could account for individual variability in weight loss, participants were grouped based on their diet-induced BM change between week 0 and week 14. Participants were classified as responders if they lost ≥5% and non-responders if they lost ≤3% of their initial BM.

All participants who completed both measures days and both free-living PA and EI measurement periods will be included in the analyses. For the physical activity data to be valid >22 hours of data per day had to be recorded on at least five days (midnight to midnight) including at least one weekend day.

q11.value: In total, 613 individuals (291 commercial diet) responded to the various recruitment methods. Of those 517 were excluded for various reasons and 96 (49 commercial diet) were recruited to the study. A further 12 withdrew from the study and 4 were excluded resulting in a final sample of 80 (37 commercial diet). Categorisation of participants as responders (≥5% of their initial BM) or non-responders (≤3% of their initial BM) resulted in 6 participants being excluded (BM change of 3.1 - 4.9% of their initial BM) from sub sample analyses leaving a sample size of 74 (responders 41 and non-responders 33).

question.value: Weight loss programme: commercial diet (low energy dense) or self-led diet (calorie restricted). For the purpose of this study, data were analysed with both diet intervention groups combined (one level). There were no specific research questions pertaining to the type of diet used to induce weight loss. Rather, the study sought to understand whether diet-induced weight loss can be predicted based on early and early-late change in free-living PA, SB, sleep and energy and macronutrient intake. Participants were then categorised based on their change in body mass (two levels); ≥5% (responders) or ≤3% (non-responders).

Body mass, waist circumference, body composition (fat mass and fat-free mass), resting metabolic rate, total daily energy intake, macronutrient intake, energy density, non-exercise physical activity, sedentary behaviour, sleep were measured between weeks 2-4 and weeks 12-14. Further details about measurement methods and procedures are provided above in the ‘Sampling and data collection procedures’ section.

ANCOVA controlling for baseline BM and programme type will be performed to determine whether there is a significant change in body weight between week 0 and 14.  ANCOVA controlling for baseline BM and programme type will also be performed to determine whether there is a significant change in BM, FM, FFM, WC, RMR, total daily energy intake, macronutrient intake, energy density, non-exercise physical activity, sedentary behaviour and sleep between week 2 and 14.
Participants will be categorised based on their percentage BM change between week 0 and 14. The difference in baseline sample characteristics between the responders (>5% weight loss) and non-responders (<3% weight loss) will be assessed using univariate ANCOVA controlling for  baseline BM and programme type. To compare early and early-late change in free-living PA, SB, sleep, energy and macronutrient intake data between groups 2 (week: early and post-intervention) x 2 (group: responders and non-responders) mixed ANCOVAs will be performed controlling for baseline BM and programme type. Where appropriate Greenhouse-Geisser probability levels will be used to adjust for sphericity. All main effects and interaction effects will be examined with Bonferroni post hoc tests.
Multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted, controlling for baseline BM and programme type, to understand whether diet-induced weight loss can be predicted based on early and early-late change (difference between week 3 and 12) in free-living PA, SB, sleep and energy and macronutrient intake. Statistical analysis will be performed using IBM SPSS for Windows (Chicago, Illinois, Version 24) and significance will be set at p < .05.

q19.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the ANCOVAs, post hoc tests and multiple linear regression suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post hoc Bonferroni test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q20.value: An outlier is any data point more than 1.5 interquartile ranges (IQRs) below the first quartile or above the third quartile. If outliers are present, analyses will be run with and without the data point and any differences will be reported.

q21.value: If a participant has missing data for any of the outcome measures, they will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: HIV Prevention in MENA Countries: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: This is a scoping review protocol based on the framework developed by Arksey and O’Malley (2005). We are completing a scoping review on HIV prevention strategies in the Middle East North Africa region.

summary.value:
This registration is a protocol for our scoping review of prevention strategies for HIV in the Middle East North Africa region (MENA). We will 1) identify our research questions, 2) describe our search strategy and inclusion/exclusion criteria, 3) describe our process for study selection, 4) list the data variables we will extract from each study, and 5) describe how we will summarize and report the results. 

Rationale
While much data are available regarding the global HIV epidemic, comparatively little is known relative to HIV in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. According to 2018 global health data sources, the MENA region has the lowest HIV prevalence in the world (less than 0.1%), 240,000 people recorded living with HIV and 20,000 new HIV infections. Unfortunately, annual new infections are rising because prevention programs are not reaching those who need them. It is important to note, that public health HIV prevention programs are especially important in this region as access to school-based sex education is limited, with little or no focus on sexually transmitted infections. As a result, education on HIV, and subsequent HIV awareness among young people, tends to be poor. Our review is important as it will identify different prevention programs utilized across the region and their respective efficacy. Our findings will help identify where prevention programs are needed within the region and strategies that have worked. These findings will help medical and public health personnel across the region develop and implement prevention programs for the general population and high risk groups within the region. 

Research Questions 
•	Determine the range and efficacy of HIV prevention strategies in the MENA Region
•	What are the barriers to implementing HIV prevention strategies in the MENA region?
•	What cultural aspects are important to consider when implementing HIV prevention strategies in the MENA region?

Identifying Relevant Studies

Information Sources
•	Medline via Ovid
•	Embase 
•	Global Health
•	Scopus
•	PsycINFO
•	WHO IRIS – specifically the Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean: https://apps.who.int/iris/ 
•	World Bank documents: http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/docsearch/topic/674854

Search Strategy 
Main concepts included:
•	HIV
•	MENA countries
•	Prevention strategies
o	Prevent*
o	Intervention, initiative, strategy, program, policy
o	Information, communication, awareness, mass media, television
o	Condoms
o	Health and sex education
o	Needle/syringe exchange programs

registration_responses.summary:
This registration is a protocol for our scoping review of prevention strategies for HIV in the Middle East North Africa region (MENA). We will 1) identify our research questions, 2) describe our search strategy and inclusion/exclusion criteria, 3) describe our process for study selection, 4) list the data variables we will extract from each study, and 5) describe how we will summarize and report the results. 

Rationale
While much data are available regarding the global HIV epidemic, comparatively little is known relative to HIV in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. According to 2018 global health data sources, the MENA region has the lowest HIV prevalence in the world (less than 0.1%), 240,000 people recorded living with HIV and 20,000 new HIV infections. Unfortunately, annual new infections are rising because prevention programs are not reaching those who need them. It is important to note, that public health HIV prevention programs are especially important in this region as access to school-based sex education is limited, with little or no focus on sexually transmitted infections. As a result, education on HIV, and subsequent HIV awareness among young people, tends to be poor. Our review is important as it will identify different prevention programs utilized across the region and their respective efficacy. Our findings will help identify where prevention programs are needed within the region and strategies that have worked. These findings will help medical and public health personnel across the region develop and implement prevention programs for the general population and high risk groups within the region. 

Research Questions 
•	Determine the range and efficacy of HIV prevention strategies in the MENA Region
•	What are the barriers to implementing HIV prevention strategies in the MENA region?
•	What cultural aspects are important to consider when implementing HIV prevention strategies in the MENA region?

Identifying Relevant Studies

attributes.title: Do non-financial incentives improve performance of frontline NGO workers? A field experiment in India.

q1.value: Do non-financial incentives improve performance of frontline NGO workers? A field experiment in India

q2.value: Karnamadakala Rahul Sharma, Mark Buntaine, Matthew Potoski

q3.value:
Many NGOs and government agencies implement programs through remotely located field offices and offer services that generate difficult-to-measure benefits. In these cases, it can be very challenging for managers to motivate frontline staff because both the inputs and outcomes of the dispersed activities are difficult to monitor and measure. Because of monitoring and measurement challenges, managers then face difficulties in specifying contracts with frontline providers, monitoring their progress, or providing enforceable rewards or penalties for performance.

	In the case of our partner MYRADA, these challenges are pronounced. MYRADA offers support to self-help groups of poor, rural women through a network of offices and field agents. The head office would like their federated offices to be financially self-sustaining by providing basic financial services that generate revenue, but they would also like agents to provide broader advice, consultations, and information to self-help groups in ways that are unlikely to be monetized. Finding ways to motivate frontline providers to provide difficult-to-measure services effectively is a major organizational problem. Because the input and outcomes of these activities are not easily measurable for the head office, typical ways of solving principal-agent problems like contracting for performance are not viable.

	We provide a test of whether non-financial incentives and motivations improve the performance of agents on dimensions that are difficult for principals to measure. In particular, we experimentally test whether training for frontline workers that (1) highlight moral values; (2) reinforce social norms; and (3) make beneficiary well-being salient through structured face-to-face interactions, can improve performance on tasks that defy typical strategies that principals have to improve the performance of their agents. Because these challenges are likely to be widespread in areas where NGOs and government agencies provide dispersed services that generate public goods, we anticipate that the results from this study will inform the strategies of a much broader set of organizations that aim to motivate providers when performance is difficult to observe.

q4.value:
We will test two primary hypotheses. Number is [brackets] indicates the outcome measure from the survey in Appendix B relevant to testing the hypothesis. We will create a single index from the outcome measures mentioned in [brackets] for each hypothesis. Further, we will also report the disaggregated tests for individual tasks both with and without Benjamini-Hochberg corrections for each outcome measure as a secondary analysis. 

H1: Treated agents will receive higher performance ratings for difficult-to-measure services as compared to control agents. [Appendix B: B1]

H2: Improvements in difficult-to-measure services will be larger than improvements in measurable services as a function of treatment. [Appendix B: B1]

We will test the following heterogeneous treatment effects. The question number measuring the variable for which heterogeneous effects are being estimated is mentioned in []. 

Agents with low baseline performance scores will improve more than agents with high baseline performance scores. [Appendix B: B1]

Agents with shorter tenure in MYRADA will have larger improvement in performance as a result of treatment than agents with longer tenure. [Appendix C: C1(6)]

Agents serving a smaller number of SHG groups will have larger improvement in performance as a result of treatment than agents serving more SHGs. [Number of SHGs served computed from baseline sample]

Agents who live in the same block as the villages they are serving will have larger improvement in performance as a result of treatment than agents who are living further away. [Appendix C: C1(9)]

The p values will be one-sided in the direction of the hypothesized relationship and based on a randomization inference procedure.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q11.value: We have conducted the baseline survey described in the project. Baseline performance information is being used for blocking and randomization. We are pre-registering before treatment is assigned and the endline survey is conducted. Therefore we do not have any information on how performance changes as a result of treatment at this point.

attributes.title: Cash transfers and household capacity to cope with idiosyncratic health shocks: A systematic review
attributes.description: This review aims to provide a quantitative summary of the impact of cash transfers on poor households’ capacity to cope with idiosyncratic health shocks. For this, we will study the effect of cash transfers on household consumption and/or expenditure growth, and use of coping strategies in response to this type of shock.

q1.value: William E. Rudgard, Delia Boccia, Elizabeth Williamson, Liam Smeeth, Ali Bargu, Fabio Veras

q2.value: Cash transfers help households to cope with idiosyncratic health shocks by supporting accumulation of wealth in advance of shocks, and guaranteeing regular and predictable income after shocks occur.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review of twelve electronic bibliographic databases and nine websites

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Information sources: We will search a total of twelve electronic bibliographic databases across the fields of economics, education, psychology, and healthcare using English-language terms. We will supplement bibliographic database searches by searching a total of nine websites.

The search string will be composed of intervention (Part 1), outcome (Part 2), and country filter (Part 3, Part 4, and Part 5). The search strings for bibliographic databases are included in the Supplementary Material of the Review Protocol.

q11.value: References returned from bibliographic database searching will be downloaded into a reference management software (Zotero). Titles and abstracts will be deduplicated and screened for full text review. Full text review will then be conducted for studies to be included in the review. Reasons for inclusion/exclusion at full text review stage will be noted on the study screening form.

question.value:
Intervention: Conditional or unconditional cash transfers. The review will use the same definition of these types of cash transfer as used in the Rigorous Review of Impacts of Cash Transfers by Bastagli et al. (1). Namely, all programmes and policies should include a cash payment component and be delivered by the state or non-governmental organisations. Programmes and policies will either be funded out of general taxation or donor-funded. As such, social insurance cash transfers financed through employer and employee contributions will not be covered in the review. However, non-contributory social pensions will be included. The review will not consider contributory social security transfers, contributory pensions, or private transfers such as remittances and religious donations (e.g. zakat). Social funds and public works programmes will also be excluded.

Outcome: Either a) the change in household consumption or expenditure in response to an idiosyncratic health shock, and/or b) household use of coping strategies in response to an idiosyncratic health shock. An idiosyncratic health shock is defined as the onset of an illness affecting an individual that triggers a sudden decline in regular household income and includes: disease, injury, disability, or death (terminal illness) (2). Both acute (lasting less than one month) and chronic (lasting longer than one month) forms of idiosyncratic health shock will be included. All approaches for measuring idiosyncratic health shocks will also be included, for example: single-item measures, validated multi-item measures, clinical diagnosis, and laboratory confirmation.

Idiosyncratic health shocks are distinct from covariate health shocks, which are adverse events that affect whole communities, regions, or whole countries and include events like disease epidemics. It was chosen not study the impact of cash transfers on households’ ability to cope with covariate health hocks as unlike for idiosyncratic shocks, this kind of shock has widespread effects on local markets (labour, food, credit etc.), which alters the coping strategies that are available to households.
Extracted effect estimates will be summarised using forest plots. A meta-analysis will be conducted if the review returns enough studies.

attributes.title: A systematic review of methods for quantitative evaluation of canal transportation: three-dimensional image methods
attributes.description: A systematic review of methods for quantitative evaluation of canal transportation

summary.value:
This systematic review was conducted in accordance with PRISMA guidelines for reporting systematic reviews and meta-analyses (Moher et al. 2009). 
An electronic search was performed to identify the available studies on canal transportation in four databases: PubMed, Web of Science, Scopus, and Science Direct, using the following terms: “root canal preparation,” “transportation,” “aberration,” “undesirable,” “center,” and “error.”  The search was performed in the English language on December 2018 and updated in March 2020. 
The question under review was not framed according to the PICO format. The present systematic review aimed to compare root canal trasportation methods. Therefore, the focused question was following: “What are the 3DI methods used for quantitative evaluation of canal transportation?”  
The inclusion criteria were the description or use of any kind of quantitative canal transportation evaluation method. Articles were deemed non-relevant and excluded when inclusion criteria were not met.

attributes.title: s news to blame?  Analyzing the effects of more news on affective polarization and other outcomes
attributes.description:
Many scholars accept that democracies function best when citizens are up-to-date on political events and knowledgeable about the issues of the day (e.g., Delli Carpini & Keeter, 1996). Thus, news exposure has been seen as normatively beneficial, and citizens are expected to attend to the news (as reected, for instance, in social desirability bias leading to overreporting of news consumption in survey self-reports; Prior, 2009). Yet, the current media environment makes it possible for citizens to avoid news altogether, which could decrease political knowledge and engagement (Delli Carpini & Keeter, 1996). It may be equally problematic that those who decide to tune in to political outlets have unprecedented opportunity to consume like-minded news, which may in part be to blame for increasing attitude (e.g., Levendusky, 2013) and affective polarization, or the animosity between people who identify with opposing political parties (e.g., Garrett et al., 2014). In this project, we problematize the notion of news exposure being necessarily democratically desirable and, in so doing, we offer a novel take on the problem of polarization.

We propose that increasing people's news exposure will exacerbate both attitude and affective polarization. We rely on group identity as a major mechanism underlying these effects. As people are exposed to news, political issues, parties, policies, and different sociopolitical groups become more salient in their minds, regardless of the ideology of the news consumed. Therefore, people learn and/or are reminded of the positions of their political in-group as well as the out-group. Because people tend to use group cues and their own political identity to make sense of the political world, they often adopt an opinion that more closely matches their in-group, increasing attitude polarization. During this process, group identity also becomes more salient, increasing affective polarization or negative attitudes toward the political out-group.

We also suspect that increasing news exposure will lead to more negative perceptions of the political system, lowering support for compromise and also increasing perceived levels of polarization and of attribution to negative intentions to the out-party (i.e., attribution of malevolence). In addition to these effects, we also explore the effects of increased news consumption on an under-studied factor, namely individual general well-being. Finally, in order to provide a balanced perspective on the impact of news, we also address the expected democratically beneffcial effects of increased political knowledge and participatory intentions.

In sum, this project addresses a fundamental question: "In what ways is news of any kind harmful, and in what ways is it beneffcial?" To test these effects, we incentivized participants in our ongoing panel to increase their news consumption for 12 days (the treatment). We include this experiment at the end of the second wave of a 3-wave panel study in Poland. 2,138 respondents completed wave 1 and were invited to the second wave. We randomly assign wave 2 respondents into this "more news" treatment group with a .6 probability. The rest are assigned to a control group and do not receive any instructions regarding altering their news diet. Our approach is novel in that we look at the effects of increasing news consumption in general (i.e., altering an individual's news diet) as opposed to the effect of exposure to a single article or browsing session, using an experimental design in a naturalistic setting. This may also be the first study to address various distinct effects of news consumption using both self-reported measures as well as observational methods in the form of online browsing data that the study participants voluntarily submitted.

In the analyses, we aim to establish the effects of increasing news exposure while also testing whether these effects depend on people's prior levels of (likeminded) news consumption.

Attitude Strength
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H1 Respondents in the treatment group will have stronger issue attitudes, when compared to both those in the control group and to their pre-treatment attitude strength.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H1a The strengthening effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.


Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H1b The strengthening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.



Attitude Importance
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H2 Respondents who consumed more news will view a set of political issues as more personally important, compared to both respondents in the control group and to their own pre-treatment issue importance measures.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H2a The strengthening effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H2b The strengthening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.



Affective Polarization
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------

H3 The levels of (support/opposition to the government- | ideology- | issue-)based affective polarization will be higher for respondents who followed more news for 12 days, compared to respondents in the control group and to their pre-treatment levels of affective polarization.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H3a The strengthening effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H3b The strengthening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.



Attribution of Malevolance
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H4 Respondents who consume more news for 12 days will be more likely to perceive
that their political opponents want to harm the country, compared to respondents
in the control group and to their prior levels of attribution of malevolence.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H4a The strengthening effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H4b The strengthening effect will be stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.



Support for Compromise
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H5 Respondents who are exposed to more news for 12 days will be less likely to believe that politicians should be willing to compromise, relative to the control group and to their pre-test levels of support for compromise.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H5a The negative effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H5b The negative effect will be stronger



Perceived Polarization
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H6 Respondents who are exposed to more news for 12 days will be more likely to perceive political polarization as a prevalent phenomenon, compared to those in the control group and their pretest levels of perceived polarization.

Treatment x Prior levels of news consumption
---------
H6a The strengthening effect will be weaker among those with higher prior levels of news exposure.

Treatment x Prior levels of like-minded news consumption
---------
H6b The strengthening effect will stronger among those with higher prior levels of like-minded news exposure.



Political Participation and Knowledge
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H7 Respondents who are exposed to more news for 12 days will know more about recent political events than those in a control group.


H8 Respondents who are exposed to more news for 12 days will have greater participatory intentions, relative to the respondents in a control group and to their pre-treatment participatory intentions.



Well-Being
---------------------------
---------------------------

Treatment
---------
H9a Being exposed to more news for 12 days will diminish respondents' well-being relative to the well-being of the respondents in the control group.

attributes.title: Cannabidiol as a supplement: a scoping review

q2.value: Ingeborg Spildo, Hilde Stromme, Gro Haarklou Mathisen, Lillebeth Larun

q3.value:
Cannabidiol (CBD) is an active substance from the cannabis sativa plant, which is associated with a variety of health effects (1). With the exception of a few drugs that require a medical prescription, cannabidiol cannot legally be sold in most European countries, including Norway. It may contain a small amount of Tetrahydrocannabinol/Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). THC is the psychoactive substance in cannabis and considered an illegal drug independent of dosage in most European countries, including Norway. 

In a report to the Norwegian Ministry of Health and Care Services, the Norwegian Medicines Agency has recommended that that the legislation is clarified concerning whether or not products containing > 0.2% THC should be classified as narcotics (4).  If the Ministry decides that products with less than 0.2% THC should not be considered as narcotics, cannabidiol supplements will be considered in the Norwegian marked. The Norwegian Ministry of Health and Care Services is awaiting the results from novel food applications and a statement from The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). If EFSA approves the novel food applications, there is reason to believe that cannabidiol supplements will be considered legal in the EU countries. As of February 2020 two novel food applications have been submitted to EFSA where the CBD dosage set to is 130 mg and 150 mg (2). The U.S Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has no dosage recommendation for cannabidiol as a supplement (3). 

Supplements are usually sold in specialty shops, online, and food- and drugstores. There is no need for a medical prescription from a doctor. There is normally established an upper daily intake and a recommended dosage. In European countries, supplements are regulated with approved health claims. Cannabidiol is an active substance in a few drugs that require a medical prescription. Normally composition of substance and dosages are different in prescription drugs and supplements. Because it is not established which dosage of cannabidiol that will be legal as a supplement in Norway or in the EU, there is no cutoff or set on CBD dosage in this scoping review. The upper daily intake for supplements will probably be lower than in the prescribed drugs. In the review, we will discuss whether the current literature can inform about the effects of CBD in dosages relevant for CBD supplements. THC dosage cutoff is set to 0.2% THC based on a suggestion from The Norwegian Medicines Agency on THC dosage in CBD products for the Norwegian market (4). The registered prescription drugs contains a higher dosage of THC than 0.2%.

In preparations for the review, we searched for articles on cannabidiol as a supplement. We did not find any scoping reviews about cannabidiol as a supplement, and no other effect studies directly concerning supplements. This may be because “supplement” was not present in the title or abstracts of possibly relevant articles. The research field for cannabidiol as a supplement new and few studies have been published. This makes it reasonable to assume that the majority of the articles included in this review will not concern cannabidiol as a supplement, but cannabidiol as prescribed drugs and unregistered drugs made specifically for the study. 


The aim of this scoping review is to map the available literature to provide an overview of research on health effects related to different doses of cannabidiol, and to identify knowledge gaps.
 
Research questions: 
1.	What are the health outcomes addressed?
2.	Which doses of CBD have been studied?
3.	For which CBD doses are health effects reported, and are these doses relevant for supplements?

See attachment for the full study protocol.

No statistical models. Descriptive analysis due to the scoping review method.
